facts.text: Kaiseri Begam respondent No. 2 sold a plot and two houses in mohalla Gher Abdul Rahman Khan, Qasba Milak, Tehsil Milak, District Rampur, to the appellants on December 4, 1953.
The first respondent Labh Singh owned the adjacent house and claimed pre-emption on the ground of vicinage after making the usual demands.
Suit for pre-emption filed by Labh Singh in the court of Munsif, Rampur.

Munsif by judgment dated September 25, 1955 held that there was a general custom of pre-emption in the town of Milak, Labh Singh entitled to pre-empt and had performed the Talabs, but dismissed the suit because the sale did not include a strip of land 3 feet 6 inches wide between Labh Singh's house and the property sold. No order about costs.
Appeal filed by Labh Singh to District Judge, Rampur; present appellants filed objections/cross-objections.
District Judge, Rampur allowed the appeal and dismissed the cross-objections.
Appellants filed second appeal in Allahabad High Court (Second Appeal No. 620 of 1957).
Mr. Justice V. D. Bhargava referred the question to Division Bench: Whether right of pre-emption contrary to Art. 19(1)(f) read with Art. 13, or saved by cl. 5 of Art. 19.
Division Bench held law of pre-emption on vicinage saved by Art. 19(5), not void under Art. 13; dismissed second appeal.
High Court certified the case for appeal to Supreme Court.

legal_issues.text: Whether the right of pre-emption on the ground of vicinage is contrary to Art. 19(1)(f) read with Art. 13 of the Constitution, or saved by clause 5 of Art. 19.
Whether custom having the force of law is included in 'laws in force' under Art. 13(1) and subject to fundamental rights under Part III, particularly Art. 19(1)(f).

petitioner_arguments.text: The ruling in Bhau Ram v. B. Baijnath Singh applies, holding law of pre-emption on vicinage imposes unreasonable restrictions on Art. 19(1)(f) and is void; no advantage to public, prevents inter-religion/race/caste acquisition contrary to Art. 15.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Bhau Ram v. B. Baijnath Singh; Art. 19(1)(f), Art. 15

respondent_arguments.text: Bhau Ram concerned legislative measure (s.10 Rewa State Pre-emption Act), not custom; custom originates from Mohammedan law or contract in village communities; Arts. 14, 15 apply only to State (Art. 12), custom not 'law' under Art. 13(3)(b); requires reconsideration of customary pre-emption on vicinage.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Digambar Singh v. Ahmad Said Khan; Art. 13(3)(a), (b); Art. 12, 14, 15

respondent_arguments.text: Definition of 'law in force' in Art. 13(3)(b) excludes custom; Art. 13(3)(a) definition applies only to cl. 2, not cl. 1.

court_reasoning.text: Bhau Ram ruling on statute law of pre-emption on vicinage being void under Art. 19(1)(f) applies equally to custom; reasons (unreasonable restrictions on vendor/vendee, no public advantage, contrary to Art. 15) same.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Restrictions on right to acquire, hold, dispose property unreasonable.

court_reasoning.text: Custom having force of law is 'law' under Art. 13(3)(a), applicable to Art. 13(1); 'laws in force' includes customs/usages; definitions control cl. 1; otherwise fundamental rights ineffective against many pre-Constitution laws; custom not made by State but still subject.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Both definitions in Art. 13(3) apply to cl. 1; inclusive definition of 'laws in force' amplifies, does not restrict.

holdings.text: Law of pre-emption on ground of vicinage, whether statutory or customary, imposes unreasonable restrictions on Art. 19(1)(f) and is void.
Custom or usage having force of law in territory of India is included in 'all laws in force' under Art. 13(1) and subject to Part III fundamental rights.

precedents_cited.case_name: Bhau Ram v. B. Baijnath Singh
precedents_cited.relevance: Held statutory pre-emption on vicinage void under Art. 19(1)(f); reasoning extends to custom.

precedents_cited.case_name: Digambar Singh v. Ahmad Said Khan
precedents_cited.relevance: Cited by respondent for history of customary pre-emption from Mohammedan law or contract.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Art. 13 defines 'law' to include custom; pre-emption on vicinage violates Art. 19(1)(f), not saved by 19(5).

statutes_cited.name: Rewa State Pre-emption Act, 1946
statutes_cited.relevance: Considered in Bhau Ram; statutory basis distinguished by respondent but applied analogously.

outcome.summary: Appeal succeeds; customary right of pre-emption on ground of vicinage held void under Art. 19(1)(f) as interpreted through Art. 13; lower court decrees allowing pre-emption set aside.
outcome.relief_granted: Appeal allowed; suit for pre-emption dismissed.

key_quotes.text: If this ruling applies the present appeal must succeed.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Indicates outcome based on application of Bhau Ram.

key_quotes.text: The reasons given by this Court to hold statute law void apply equally to a custom.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: There are two compelling reasons why custom and usage having in the territory of India the force of the law must be held to be contemplated by the expression all laws in force.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core reasoning on Art. 13 including customs under fundamental rights.
